title: Graphical analysis - effect of U.S. ban on CFCs

content.question: In 1978, the United States banned the use of <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in aerosols. Based on the data in the graph, which of the following best explains the effect of this ban as a solution to decrease global <math alttext="C F C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production?

choices.label: The ban on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> led to a decrease of <math alttext="C F C 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC-</mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C F C 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC-</mtext><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> production by more than <math alttext="15 percent" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> between 1978 and 1980, which supports the ban as an effective solution to reduce global <math alttext="C F C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production.

The ban on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in aerosols led to an increase in <math alttext="C F C 113" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC-</mtext><mn>113</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> production for use in refrigerants and air conditioners in the United States, which led to a <math alttext="10 percent " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> overall increase in global <math alttext="C F C " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production between 1970 and 1980.

The ban on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> also led to a decrease in <math alttext="H C F C " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HCFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production beginning in 1980, reducing the reliance on chlorinated chemicals used in industrial processes and greatly reducing stratospheric ozone depletion.

The ban on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in aerosols in the United States was not effective on a global scale because it led to an increase in reports of skin cancer and cataracts in patients in the Southern Hemisphere from 1970 to 2000.

content.answer: The ban on <math alttext="C F C s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFCs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> led to a decrease of <math alttext="C F C 11" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC-</mtext><mn>11</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="C F C 12" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC-</mtext><mn>12</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> production by more than <math alttext="15 percent" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>%</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> between 1978 and 1980, which supports the ban as an effective solution to reduce global <math alttext="C F C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CFC</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> production.

skill.text: Skill 7.D: Use data and evidence to support a potential solution.
